links.description: The 52-hertz whale is an individual whale of unidentified species, which calls at the very unusual frequency of 52 Hz. Sacrificial part - Wikipedia
links.description: A sacrificial part is a part of a machine or product that is intentionally engineered to fail under excess mechanical stress, electrical stress, or other unexpected and dangerous situations. The sacrificial part is engineered to fail first, and thus protect other parts of the system.

links.title: Shear pin - Wikipedia
links.description: A shear pin is a mechanical detail designed to allow a specific outcome to occur once a predetermined force is applied. It can either function as a safeguard designed to break to protect other parts, or as a conditional operator that will not allow a mechanical device to operate until the correct force is applied.

links.title: Kōban - Wikipedia
links.description: A kōban (交番, kōban) is a small neighborhood police station found in Japan. The term is also used to refer to the smallest organizational unit in a modern Japanese Prefectural police department.[1] Small kōban buildings, staffed by uniformed officers at around 6,000 locations all over the country,[2] are the bases for community policing activities which complement the work of larger, central police stations.

links.description: Karōshi (過労死), which can be translated literally as "overwork death" in Japanese, is occupational sudden mortality. links.title: Net settlement - Wikipedia
links.description:
A net settlement is the process by which banks calculate the collective total of all transactions on any given day.
[1] Credit and debit transactions are recorded on the clearing house books throughout the business day; final settlement of the net transactions, the credits less the debits, occurs when funds due to a bank are credited to its reserve account by a Federal Reserve Bank.

links.description: Nostro and vostro (from Italian, nostro and vostro; English, 'ours' and 'yours') are accounting terms used to distinguish an account held for another entity from an account another entity holds. The entities in question are almost always, but need not be, banks.

links.title: Time-based One-time Password algorithm - Wikipedia
links.description: The Time-based One-Time Password algorithm (TOTP) is an extension of the HMAC-based One-time Password algorithm (HOTP) generating a one-time password by instead taking uniqueness from the current time. It has been adopted as Internet Engineering Task Force[1] standard RFC 6238,[1] is the cornerstone of Initiative For Open Authentication (OATH), and is used in a number of two-factor authentication systems.

links.title: BonziBuddy - Wikipedia
links.description: BonziBuddy, stylized as BonziBUDDY, was a freeware desktop assistant made by Joe and Jay Bonzi. Upon a user's choice the on-screen agent would share jokes and facts, manage downloading using its download manager, sing songs, talk and other functions.[1]

links.title: Arno Appenzeller on Twitter
links.description:
“Wow @AppleSupport in Apple Stores becoming more and more ridiculous. Getting an appointment at Genius Bar is very difficult and then you have to wait 2 weeks for a keyboard replacement. 
Store Manager‘s advice was to buy a new MacBook for the wait and then return it 🙄”

links.title: Simon Davies on Twitter
links.description: “Come on @AppleSupport @Apple 2 mth old MacBookPro. Sticking keyboard. Wasted appt at Genius Bar. 14 day repair offered on known issue. Options: loan replacement laptop for £300 or 'buy a new Mac and return within 14 days' as cover. Crazy, just give me a new one as it's faulty!”

links.title: Casey on Twitter
links.description: “@Mauronic @dhh I had the same interaction with the Genius Bar. They said I could just buy a new one laptop & return it later. That sounded crazy to me! Turned out they could replace the two bad keys on the spot and I didn't need to buy a new laptop. But now those keys are broken again :(”

links.title: Amanda Levitt on Twitter
links.description: “Found out getting my macbook battery replaced takes 3 to 5 business days. The apple employee at the genius bar told me that some people buy a laptop and then return it after the repair has been done.”

links.title: 13-inch MacBook Pro (non Touch Bar) Battery Replacement Program - Apple Support
links.description: Apple has determined that, in a limited number of 13-inch MacBook Pro (non Touch Bar) units, a component may fail causing the built-in battery to expand. This is not a safety issue and Apple will replace eligible batteries, free of charge. Affected units were manufactured between October 2016 and October 2017 and eligibility is determined by the product serial number.

links.title: amiga:rad [Wizardry and Steamworks]
links.description: All operating systems have the ability to create a disk or drive in RAM such that the resulting disk can be accessed either as a hard-drive or a floppy and be manipulated by the operating system just like a physical drive. All Amiga versions create a RAM drive on the Workbench that is precisely that: a drive that can be read and written to just like any other volume. A RAM drive is inherently volatile such that after a reboot, the RAM drive is c...

links.title: List of Linux distributions that run from RAM - Wikipedia
links.description: This is a list of Linux distributions that can be run entirely from the computer's RAM. That ability allows them to be very fast, since reading and writing data from/to RAM is much faster than on a hard disk drive. Many of these operating systems will load from a removable media such as a Live CD or a Live USB stick. A "frugal" install can also often be completed, allowing boot up from a hard disk drive instead.
